moves.4... g6: although part of modern theory, this fianchetto is not very common, in this opening: usually follows dxe5, dxe5, Bg4...
moves.5. Ng5: theory dictates c4, Nb6, Nc3, dxe5, dxe5, soon followed by trading Queens; White decides to hold on to c4 for a while longer and poses an early threat: Nxf7, Kxf7, Qf3+, followed by Qxd5; after Bg7, Qf3, Be6 (forced), White can consider Nxe6...
moves.5... dxe5 6. dxe5 Bg7 7. c4: worth considering is Bc4, c6, e6, Bxe6, Nxe6, fxe6, 0-0, before trading Queens...
moves.10. f4 a6 11. Bd2 Nb8c6 12. Bc3 Bf5: trying to force a way towards c2; more promising for Black was f6, exf6, exf6, in a somewhat better position...
moves.13. Be2 Rd8 14. g4 Bd3: missing the gravity of the situation, Black gets careless: best was Bc8, h3, f6, or at least h6, Nxf7, Kxf7, gxf5, gxf5...
moves.15. e6: this is what Black missed: not only is White threatening Nxf7, but also Bxg7 or exf7+...
moves.15... Nd4: or f6, Nf7, Rd4, Bxd4, Nxd4, Bxd3, Nxd3+, Kd2, Nxf4, Nxh8, Bxh8, Nc2...
moves.16... fxe6: Black decides to eliminate all threats at the cost of a piece; better was a5, Nxf7, Rf8, or f6, Nf7, Nbc6...
moves.17. Bxb4 Rf8: again, not the best decision: best is h6, Nf3, Nc6...
moves.18... b5: forced: after c6, Rd1, h6, Rxd3, hxg5, fxg5, Nf3+, Ke2, Rxd3, Kxd3, Black is losing...
moves.19. cxb5 axb5 20. Bd1 Rxf4 21. Bd2 Rf8: Black is just holding everything together: but now, White is unleashed...
moves.22. Rc1: Bd3 is trapped, so White is preparing Rc3...
moves.22... h6: this move is long overdue, and cannot help Black anymore...
moves.24. Rxc2: much stronger than Bxc2, Bxc3, bxc3, hxg5, Bxd3, Rxd3, Nxb5, Kd7!
moves.25... Bxc2 26. Bxb5+ Kf7 27. Nxc2 Bxb2 2: already the winning move: with the Bishop pair guarding the free pawn, promotion is only a matter of time...
moves.28... Kg7 29. Rf1 Rfh8 30. Rf2 Be5: useless and wrong: White will be more than happy to give up h2, granting free passage for the a-pawn; better Rh4, Rg2, Rh3...
moves.31. Nb4: of course, threatening to trade the all important Bishop after Nc6; so Black has to react and is forced into trading...
moves.31... Rxh2 32. Rxh2 Bxh2 33. a5: Blacks' DSB is cornered out, by his own c-pawn: this gives Whites' a-pawn free passage...
moves.33... Rb8: practically the only move, to counter Nc6; after c5, Nc6, Ra8/c8, Bxg5, wraps it all up...
moves.34. Bc4: Whites' Bishop pair rules supremely: after Bf4, Bc3+, Kf7, a6, Ke8, Bxe6, Black has no play left; so he resigned...

gameName: Fierce Queens' taking on the Alekhine...
